Annual Conclaves Held

With the view of establishing
closer harmony among member colleges and universities, it was
learned, the Federation stages annual conferences at which the convening students discuss student
Problems and determine the year's
program.
The convention of university representatives at Princeton, in 1925,
to discuss the entrance of the United States into the World Court is
attributed as the actual beginning
of the national organization.
Survey Needs of Students

With small budgets, the N. S. F.
A. leaders have surveyed the needs
of students and have accomplished
much toward that end. Administrations and foundations have been appealed to for further financial aid.
Through affiliation with the N.
S. F. A., Johns Hopkins students
may profit by the numerous advantages of the organization, Mr.
Cone declared. The advantages
Were given as: reduced rates in foreign travel, in certain lines of merchandise ,news bulletins and the use
of the central information office.

The Violet relay team, composed
of the three stars of the meet, Frazier, Marcus, Gittenstein, scored a
triumph over the Hopkins natators.
Stern garnered five points and
Bill Reid four. The four other
points for the Blue Jays were added by the other swimmers on the
Hopkins squad. The team was
without the aid of Captain Doebler,
who could not make the trip because
of illness.
Throughout the meet, the winner was never in doubt, the New
York team being much stronger.
The meet was held in the Bronx
Union Y. M. C. A., Saturday afternoon.

their program to an audience at the
Forest Park Presbyterian Church
last Friday night.
The audience appeared to be in
an appreciative mood and frequently punctuated the club's presentation with applause. The
club, its
leaders believe, gained valuable experience by virture of their first two

excellent condition for their remaining concerts.

Portrait Presentation
Set For Commencement
Hopkins Will Get Portrait of Dr.
Charles K. Swartz in June

At the commencement exercises
of the Johns Hopkins University,
to be held in June, the portrait of
Dr. Charles K. Swartz, Collegiate
Professor of Geology, will be presented formally to the University
by the professor's former students
and friends in recognition of his 27
years' service as a teacher here.
The portrait, which has already
been completed by Thomas C. Corner, Baltimore artist, was viewed at
a private showing, Saturday, by
several officials of the Hopkins, it
was learned yesterday.

Professor H. C. Lancaster To Speak
on "Richelieu and the Drama"

Dr. E. Feise, secretary of the
Johns Hopkins Philological Association, announces a meeting for
January 22, at 11.30 A. M. in
Room 216, Gilman Hall.
The guest speaker will be Professor H. C. Lancaster ,who will
speak on the subject, "Richelieu and
the Drama."

A new committee has just been
formed to plan for proper physical
training and athletics, according to
Dean E. W. Berry, who is one of
its members. The group, which was
formed last Thursday, will make a
report of its findings to the President.
Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Director of Physical Education, heads
the committee, which is composed
of faculty members, alumni and undergraduates. It will consider, the
Dean declared, ways and means of
improving the two subjects it has
under observation. An important
topic that will be under discussion
will be the cage question.

After splitting even in its games
last week the Hopkins basketball
team will attempt to gain ground in
the state title race when it meets
two formidable opponents. Tonight
Western Maryland will furnish the
opposition while the Jays will encounter their hardest foe of the year
Thursday evening when the University of Maryland five comes up
from College Park. Should the
Black and Blue quint win these
games they would face the remainder of the schedule from a high
notch in the league.
Little is known of the Green Terrors who lock horns with Coach
Darley's team this evening at Evergreen. In the past the Westminster
College has always put out a fairly
strong five and this year's squad
apparently compares favorably with
those of past seasons.

The members of the committee,
besides Dr Abercrombie and Dean
Berry, are Dr. Ray Van Orman,
Douglas Turnbull, Jr., and H. Garland Hershey, who are graduates,
and Robert Kyle and John Heinzerling, who are seniors.

Tudor, Stuart Club Has Many
Rare Volumes, Declares French

U. of M. Compiling Fine Record

Literary Club Formed in 1923 by Sir William Osier Of the University of Maryland
little needs to be said. With a vetPossesses Unique Spenser Collection;
eran quint back this year, Burton
Valued Highly
Organized on January 16, 1923,
the Tudor and Stuart Club now
possesses one of the best collections
of early .editions of Tudor and
Stuart literary masterpieces to be
found in any university, says Dr.
J. C. French,.curator of the club and
Hopkins librarian. It is especially
fortunate in the possession of many
rare editions of Spenser's works.
The society was founded on the
gift of Sir William Osler, one of
the famous men of his time, and his
wife, Lady Osler, in memory of
their only son, Edward Revere Osler, who died from wounds received
in the World War. The original
endowment fund was augmented
from time to time, and now totals
over $40,000.
Was Inveterate Collector

Sir William Osler, who for a
long time was connected with the
Johns Hopkins Medical School, was
an inveterate book collector. To encourage his son along that line, he
bought him a copy of Izaak Walton's The Corn pleat Angler. The boy
read the volume, and after he had
caught and identified many of the

fish illustrated in the book, he decided to collect other works by the
same writer. Later on his interests
broadened, and he came to collect
other books, and to acquire a small
library. The boy, Edward Revere
Osler, designed his own Ex Libris
plate, which appears in all the books
of his collection, donated to the club
with the original endowment.
Osier Interested In Carving

Young Osler was also interested
in wood carving, and a chest carved
by him now stands in the club
rooms. The chest bears a plate
stating that it was made by Osler in
1912, when he was seventeen years
of age. When the World War broke
out, he entered the British Army.
In the service, he suffered a shell
wound that proved fatal. In 1917,
he died.
To commemorate his memory,
and to found at the Johns Hopkins
University an organization dedicated to the advancement of interest
in literature, Sir William and Lady
Osler founded the Tudor and Stuart
Club. Among the famous volumes
that formed the library of Edward

Shipley, College Park mentor, is
compiling one of the finest cage records ever made at that school. Although the loss of Gaylor, who
failed to return after the Christmas
holidays, was a blow, Shipley has
built a speedy, high-scoring team.
At the beginning of the season followers of the state quints picked
the Ravens to lead the race and with
the practical elimination of Washington College by Hopkins last
Thursday it appears that those fans
were right.
Old Liners Opened With Victory

The Old Liners opened with a
38 to 29 victory over Gallaudet and
since then has scored three victories
in the Southern Conference. Two
of these, the Washington and Lee
victory and that over Duke University, were made over the best quints
in the south.
Berger Is High Scorer

Berger, who has caused Hopkins
no little trouble in the past, is the
high scorer for the Terrapins and if
the Jays can stop him their chances
of a win will be that much better.

FOUNDED 1897

EDITORIALS

p

cil. All matters regarding activities are given over to the Student Activities Council. These two bodies are not figureheads, but have complete control over their respective fields. The S. A. Council each year
passes its budget deciding how the money paid by students for activities should be apportioned. Although we do not recommend that the
A. A. Board be given complete control of athletics, we certainly recommend that they have some say in the matter as to how the students'
money should be spent. Students themselves decide how the activities
fee should be divided, and they have a similar right in the matter of
athletics.
It would be impossible for the students to completely control athletics. This is a job that requires experience, and the full time of an
individual. Student opinion should be considered in formulating the
annual budget.

UPSETS
AST Thursday the Jay basketball five pulled the first upset in the
state collegiate race by defeating Washington College 20 to 18.
We are glad to see that Jay teams have not lost their aptitude for doing
surprising things. Not since the St. John's lacrosse game last spring
have the Jays pulled a real upset. In former years, Hopkins teams
seemed to have the habit of giving little surprise parties at rather regular intervals. Of late, however, these occasions have been conspicuous
by their absence. Let us pray for more and better surprise parties.

DEBATING AGAIN
N a rcent issue of the NEWS-LETTER we made a misstatement to
the effect that the Dean objected to the manner in which trials were
conducted for the debating council. We were misinformed on this
question. We also stated the senior tryouts were unjust. Perhaps we
were wrong as only three men appeared at the tryouts for the three

T F THE Hopkins undergraduate
1 school is ever to attain intellectual independence, it must depart from the standards established
by other American colleges. I
should like to see the College evolve
to the point where students would
be allowed perfect freedom after
two years' initial preparation—freedom to pursue their intellectual interests in unconventional style. I
would have formal lecturing abolished and in its place informal discussion between professor and student in the intimacy of small friendly groups.
The student should be allowed to
spend much of his time reading the
literature in his chosen field, absorbing culture and knowledge by
infiltration rather than hot-house
forcing. Formal examinations
would no longer harass the undergraduate although before he received a degree, he should certainly
be required to present convincing
evidence in the form of essay or
dissertation and oral examination of
his ability to correlate intelligently
the information and culture he has
amassed. St. Johns has done some-

S FOR the recreational activities in this new College, Hopkins could again contribute something of worth by swinging American colleges away from the overemphasis which has been placed on
intercollegiate athletics. Personally,
I should like to see intercollegiate
athletic competition dropped by the
Johns Hopkins, I should like to see
a return to the English idea of sport
for sport's sake rather than for the
sake of winning. And, above all, I
should like to see athletics made
available for each and every undergraduate no matter what his talents.

for the University.

expecting Hopkins to emerge from
the period of lethargy which has

C. A. has at last awakened to the
great danger of keeping 'Reds"

then I have no doubt that George
Boas and Broadus Mitchell will
keep things going from their side
of the fence.

Meeting Arranged to Discuss Cage
Fund Drive on Johns Hopkins
Campus

421 North Charles Street
Baltimore, Md.

In order to reorganize after a
comparatively inactive period, the
Varsity Club will meet on Thursday, after the assembly in the C. E.
Hall, according to Club officials.
The main business of the meeting,
it was declared, will be to discuss
the taking over of the Cage Fund
Drive on the campus by the Club.
The aims of the club, as advanced in 1927, the year of its formotion, are twofold: namely, that
of interesting high school students
in the University, and the entertainment of visiting teams.
The club, it is said, will become
active after examinations. All members are expected to be present.
Varsity letter holders who have not
received notices of the meeting, but
who are eligible for membership,
are requested to attend.

Mr. Schaal

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
Dear Sir:
In an article appearing under my
signature in the January 13 issue of
the NEWS-LETTER, it was incorrectly
asserted that a resolution passed by
the Hopkins student body pertaining
to E. A. Schaal was not forwarded
to the Central Y. M. C. A. At the
time that I attempted to verify an
interesting rumor, I questioned two
members of the Student Council.
One professed no knowledge of the
matter at all. The other, Mr. Yellott, assured me in very definite
terms that such a document had not
been addressed to the Central Y. M.
C. A. Not being able to communicate with Mr. Warlow I accepted
the information as presented to me.
But this minor discrepancy in no
manner alters either the situation
itself or the trend of my arguments
as set forth. Moreover, I take exuberant pleasure at this time in reaffirming everything else I have
written about Mr. Schaal, his liberalism, and the Liberal Club.
H. L. FRIEDBERG.

the performance given against

has also featured the Hopkins

Commission Holds Competitive Exams
For Position At Saint Elizabeth's
Hospital

A communication received from
the United States Civil Service
Commission at Washington declares that a competitive examination for Junior Medical Officer (Interne) will begin immediately. The
entrance salary is $2,000 a year, and
the examination is to fill vacancies
at Saint Elizabeth's Hospital,
Washington, D. C.
Applications must be on file with
the Manager of the Fourth U. S.
Civil Service District, Washington,
D. C., not later than February 14,
1931. Competitors must be graduates of Grade A medical schools
with a degree of M.D. received not
more than two years prior to the
closing date of applications.
Applications, however, will be accepted from fourth-year students
linder certain specific conditions.
Competitors will not be required to
report for examination at any place,
but will be rated on their education,
training, and experiences.
Information may be obtained
from the United States Civil Service Commission, Washington, D. C.,
or from the Secretary of the U. S.
Civil Service Board of Examiners
at the post office or customs house
in any city.

Tudor, Stuart Club Has Many
Rare Volumes, Declares French

U. of M. Compiling Fine Record

Literary Club Formed in 1923 by Sir William Osier Of the University of Maryland
little needs to be said. With a vetPossesses Unique Spenser Collection;
eran quint back this year, Burton
Valued Highly
Organized on January 16, 1923,
the Tudor and Stuart Club now
possesses one of the best collections
of early .editions of Tudor and
Stuart literary masterpieces to be
found in any university, says Dr.
J. C. French,.curator of the club and
Hopkins librarian. It is especially
fortunate in the possession of many
rare editions of Spenser's works.
The society was founded on the
gift of Sir William Osler, one of
the famous men of his time, and his
wife, Lady Osler, in memory of
their only son, Edward Revere Osler, who died from wounds received
in the World War. The original
endowment fund was augmented
from time to time, and now totals
over $40,000.
Was Inveterate Collector

Sir William Osler, who for a
long time was connected with the
Johns Hopkins Medical School, was
an inveterate book collector. To encourage his son along that line, he
bought him a copy of Izaak Walton's The Corn pleat Angler. The boy
read the volume, and after he had
caught and identified many of the

fish illustrated in the book, he decided to collect other works by the
same writer. Later on his interests
broadened, and he came to collect
other books, and to acquire a small
library. The boy, Edward Revere
Osler, designed his own Ex Libris
plate, which appears in all the books
of his collection, donated to the club
with the original endowment.
Osier Interested In Carving

Young Osler was also interested
in wood carving, and a chest carved
by him now stands in the club
rooms. The chest bears a plate
stating that it was made by Osler in
1912, when he was seventeen years
of age. When the World War broke
out, he entered the British Army.
In the service, he suffered a shell
wound that proved fatal. In 1917,
he died.
To commemorate his memory,
and to found at the Johns Hopkins
University an organization dedicated to the advancement of interest
in literature, Sir William and Lady
Osler founded the Tudor and Stuart
Club. Among the famous volumes
that formed the library of Edward

the Jays can stop him their chances

cil. All matters regarding activities are given over to the Student Activities Council. These two bodies are not figureheads, but have complete control over their respective fields. The S. A. Council each year

A. A. Board be given complete control of athletics, we certainly recommend that they have some say in the matter as to how the students'
money should be spent. Students themselves decide how the activities

It would be impossible for the students to completely control athletics. This is a job that requires experience, and the full time of an
individual. Student opinion should be considered in formulating the
annual budget.

UPSETS
AST Thursday the Jay basketball five pulled the first upset in the
state collegiate race by defeating Washington College 20 to 18.
We are glad to see that Jay teams have not lost their aptitude for doing
surprising things. Not since the St. John's lacrosse game last spring
have the Jays pulled a real upset. In former years, Hopkins teams
seemed to have the habit of giving little surprise parties at rather regular intervals. Of late, however, these occasions have been conspicuous
by their absence. Let us pray for more and better surprise parties.

Meeting Arranged to Discuss Cage
Fund Drive on Johns Hopkins
Campus

421 North Charles Street
Baltimore, Md.

In order to reorganize after a
comparatively inactive period, the
Varsity Club will meet on Thursday, after the assembly in the C. E.
Hall, according to Club officials.
The main business of the meeting,
it was declared, will be to discuss
the taking over of the Cage Fund
Drive on the campus by the Club.
The aims of the club, as advanced in 1927, the year of its formotion, are twofold: namely, that
of interesting high school students
in the University, and the entertainment of visiting teams.
The club, it is said, will become
active after examinations. All members are expected to be present.
Varsity letter holders who have not
received notices of the meeting, but
who are eligible for membership,
are requested to attend.

Mr. Schaal

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
Dear Sir:
In an article appearing under my
signature in the January 13 issue of
the NEWS-LETTER, it was incorrectly
asserted that a resolution passed by
the Hopkins student body pertaining
to E. A. Schaal was not forwarded
to the Central Y. M. C. A. At the
time that I attempted to verify an
interesting rumor, I questioned two
members of the Student Council.
One professed no knowledge of the
matter at all. The other, Mr. Yellott, assured me in very definite
terms that such a document had not
been addressed to the Central Y. M.
C. A. Not being able to communicate with Mr. Warlow I accepted
the information as presented to me.
But this minor discrepancy in no
manner alters either the situation
itself or the trend of my arguments
as set forth. Moreover, I take exuberant pleasure at this time in reaffirming everything else I have
written about Mr. Schaal, his liberalism, and the Liberal Club.
H. L. FRIEDBERG.

Darley had hit the right combination. Certainly the Kelly brothers,
Silverman, Brook, and Taylor
worked with more ease and speed
than any other five that has represented the Black and Blue this season.
Jays Show General Improvement

The passing, guarding, and floorwork was a great improvement on
the performance given against
Georgetown. Another improvement
was noted in that attempted field
goals were followed up by the Jays
with the advantage going to them in
many cases. With the team functioning tonight as it did against the
Shoremen a victory over the Green
Terrors might be expected.
Even Maryland, with everything
in its favor may be surprised when
the Homewood team steps out on
the floor. For Hopkins is fast building up the reputation of "upsetting
the dope bucket." The home basketeers seem to function best when
all predictions are against them.
Kelly
. Still Highlight

Don Kelly's shooting continues
to be the highlight for the Black
and Blue. The stellar guard has
averaged ten points a game and will
be among the leading scorers of the
state when the season closes. The
passing and dribbling of Silverman
has also featured the Hopkins
games. In spite of their youth and
inexperience the Jays should give
their opponents quite a few anxious
moments and a large crowd will
probably turn out for both games.

Commission Holds Competitive Exams
For Position At Saint Elizabeth's
Hospital

A communication received from
the United States Civil Service
Commission at Washington declares that a competitive examination for Junior Medical Officer (Interne) will begin immediately. The
entrance salary is $2,000 a year, and
the examination is to fill vacancies
at Saint Elizabeth's Hospital,
Washington, D. C.
Applications must be on file with
the Manager of the Fourth U. S.
Civil Service District, Washington,
D. C., not later than February 14,
1931. Competitors must be graduates of Grade A medical schools
with a degree of M.D. received not
more than two years prior to the
closing date of applications.
Applications, however, will be accepted from fourth-year students
linder certain specific conditions.
Competitors will not be required to
report for examination at any place,
but will be rated on their education,
training, and experiences.
Information may be obtained
from the United States Civil Service Commission, Washington, D. C.,
or from the Secretary of the U. S.
Civil Service Board of Examiners
at the post office or customs house
in any city.
